result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

charges.descr: Battery or Threat to Judge, Prosecutor, or Law Enforcement Officer

Defendant shall not possess or consume any alcoholic beverages or nonprescription controlled substances, or any prescription medicine for which the defendant does not have a current prescription.
Defendant shall not enter into any establishment where the primary purpose is the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
Defendant shall not drive without a valid drivers license.
Defendant shall not have any contact with officer Colt Woods or his family except for professional purposes.
Defendant shall participate in bail monitoring with John Shulta, Lafayette County Court Services Coordinator.
Defendant shall agree to random drug testing ordered by John Shulta.

11:33 AM Fred Svensson Interpreter appears. 
Defendant Alvin Alejandro Dehoyos Jr. in court and in custody.  Attorney Corinne L Frutiger in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Defendant acknowledges criminal complaint.
Court verbally reviews charges/penalties for the record.
Court finds probable cause for filing.

Court Orders: $500.00 Cash 
-No alcohol, establishment or controlled substances
-Not drive without a valid DL
-No contact with Colt Woods or his family except for professional purposes.

OR
$1,000.00 Signature with Bail Monitoring


Court informs the defendant of their right to counsel.
Defendant is provided with PD phone number and petition for court appointed counsel.
